content.description:
In the center of the east face on Window Rock are a series of perfect hand cracks that don't quite make it to the ground.  Look for a bolt below the start of two of these cracks.  The left crack is Good Times, and the right crack is Pure Pleasure.  Both are 5.7, and both are enjoyable.

There is a tree at the base of the routes to the right.  Start at this tree and traverse left on the slabs to the bolt.  Climb the right crack to its end and belay on a big ledge with horizontal placements for an anchor.  When your second gets up there, go check out the Window up and left of your belay ledge.  Huge bathtubs abound on this rock.

Descend with a one-rope rappel off a two-bolt anchor located 20 feet to climber's right of the route, landing at the tree where you started.

One Step Beyond is a face you can top rope after doing Expect No Mercy.

Start on a couple decent crimps and make a couple challenging moves before making some kind of huge reach/deadpoint 6 feet up.  Above, lay away the steep stuff and hope you get to the lip before you pump out.

Bingham's guide gives this a .11a which I felt to be a huge sandbag.  The crux moves I did were minimum .11+, after several attempts. Could be harder, or if I missed something, could be easier.

For those looking for and expecting .11a, this is a bomb.
content.location: Just right of Expect No Mercy.  Two bolt anchor atop that route.

content.description:
AKA:

Take no Prisoners

, this water groove/crack is at the left end of the east face of

Window Rock

.  The crux is down low.  After the start it's easy low angle climbing to the top.  Belay from trad anchor at top, then walk to north end for one rope rappel.  I enjoyed leading this climb despite the name.
content.protection: Standard rack, offset cams are nice.

content.description:
This right is about 60 feet right of Pure Pleasure and Good Times.  Scramble up a couple of boulders to a great hand crack with an obvious Juniper growing out of the bottom of it.

This climb has fewer facial features than Good Times and Pure Pleasure and requires more traditional crack technique.

Descend) using the same bolt repel anchors as Good Times and Pure Pleasure.
content.protection: Hand crack sized cams and hexes.

content.description: Start on the slab just left of the start to Good Times and Pure Pleasure. Climb up to a very thin pinched crack, and continue up as it widens.
content.protection: The pro is poor to non-existent for the first 30ft or so. A single rack with some small nuts and micro cams is sufficient. Finger to hand size pieces for the belay.

content.description:
In the center of the east face on Window Rock are a series of perfect hand cracks that don't quite make it to the ground.  Look for a bolt below the start of two of these cracks.  The left crack is Good Times, and the right crack is Pure Pleasure.  Both are 5.7, and both are enjoyable.

There is a tree at the base of the routes to the right.  Start at this tree and traverse left on the slabs to the bolt.  Climb the left crack to its end and belay on a big ledge with horizontal placements for an anchor.  When your second gets up there, go check out the Window up and left of your belay ledge.  Huge bathtubs abound on this rock.

Descend with a one-rope rappel off a two-bolt anchor located 20 feet to climber's right of the route, landing at the tree where you started.

On the east side of Window Rock is this obvious line, often climbed, but not listed in the latest Bingham guide.  It shares the start (and crux) with Pocket Rocket, stays in the flaring crack until it ends, crosses directly over the horizontal gash/crack about halfway up the route utilizing face holds until a second finger-sized crack is reached.  The first 3-4 moves (poor feet) are 5.9, the rest is 5.7-ish.  Going from one crack to the other may provide a modest runout if protection cannot be found in the horizontal.

NOTE: If a name is in common use for this climb, let's make that change here.
content.protection: A spot is encouraged for the start, med. - 3" gear at bottom, small - med. gear at top.  Trad anchors.
content.location: This is between the alcove containing Expect No Mercy and the parallel cracks of Good Times and Pure Pleasure on the east side of Window Rock.  Descend by walking north along the spacious ledge to rap anchors.

content.description: In the center of the east face on Window Rock is a fist crack that comes down into a large alcove.  This is Expect No Mercy.  Climb the steep face past a couple of bolts to the crack.  Pull through this pumpy fist crack roof and jam to the two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Two (or three?) draws, #3 Camalot, #3.5 Camalot (optional), #2 Camalot, a couple of long slings for the larger cams.

content.description:
In the center of the east face on Window Rock are a series of perfect hand cracks that don't quite make it to the ground.  Look for a bolt below the start of two of these cracks.  The left crack is Good Times, and the right crack is Pure Pleasure.  Both are 5.7, and both are enjoyable.  You should do these as well.  Drunken Climber is the crack to the right of these.

There is a tree at the base of the route.  Start at this tree and head up into the crack above you to its end.  Belay on a big ledge with horizontal placements for an anchor.

Descend with a one-rope rappel off a two-bolt anchor located 5 feet to climber's right of the route, landing at the tree where you started.

Note: I don't know what this route is historically called, but ``Drunken Climber'' is what we have always called it.  If you know more about this route, please speak up!

Named after an old Martian movie, a pretty nice route. Slabby, well protected crux down low into a nice, though somwhat, flaring crack. When the crack gets funky, run it out to the prominent horizontal for some gear, then wander to the top on dishes. Fun long pitch...a little spicy.
content.protection: Bolt and gear  down low when the climbing is harder, runout easy terrain up top. 70M rope will let you climb all the way to the tip top of Window rock.Scramble down to north end raps.
content.location: Backside of window rock...50 feet left of good times/pure pleasure...look for the lone bolt, connecting overlaps to the obvious crack.

content.description: Start right of the Rated "R" Route and left of Failure to launch. Move up Crack traverse right on small rail. Up the right crack then traverse left to parallel crack. Belay up on horizontal crack about 100-120ft up.
content.location: Right of the Rated "R" Route and left of Failure to launch.

content.description: Unnamed crack in the Bingham guidebook. Just right of Drunken Cowboy. Start just right of the big tree at the base of Drunken Cowboy. Work up the crack on low angle slab. Build gear anchor at the top. Rap from the chains above Drunken Cowboy (recommended) or do the 5.easyish chimney down climb to the right.  See beta pic for more information.
content.protection: Standard rack. Take a few extra pieces for a gear anchor.
